content: The Act titled "Bonuses for Cost-Cutters Act of 2013" aims to enhance cost savings. The "Bonuses for Cost-Cutters Act of 2013" amends Section 4512 of title 5, United States Code to include the identification of surplus funds or unnecessary budget authority in the responsibilities of the Inspector General of an agency or other agency employee. The "Bonuses for Cost-Cutters Act of 2013" amends Section 4512 of title 5, United States Code to include the identification of surplus funds or unnecessary budget authority in the responsibilities of the Inspector General of an agency or other agency employee. The Inspector General or designated agency employee must refer any potential surplus funds or unnecessary budget authority to the agency's Chief Financial Officer for review and possible rescission. The Chief Financial Officer of an agency must review and refer any potential surplus funds or unnecessary budget authority identified by an employee. If deemed not hindering agency effectiveness, the head of the agency transfers the amount to the general fund of the Treasury. The head of the agency transfers surplus funds or unnecessary budget authority to the general fund of the Treasury for deficit reduction, exempt from Title X of the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974. The agency head transfers surplus funds to the Treasury for deficit reduction, exempt from certain budget control regulations. The transferred amounts can also be used for debt reduction if there is no deficit, with a provision for agency heads to retain a portion for cash awards. The agency head can transfer surplus funds to the Treasury for deficit reduction or debt reduction. They can retain up to 10% for cash awards to employees who identified the surplus funds. Each agency must report any possible fraud, waste, or surplus funds to the Office of Personnel Management annually.
